required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on July 28, 2020
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Does a Patient Education Video Augment Pelvic Floor Physical Therapy Compliance?
clinical_study.official_title: Does a Patient Education Video Augment Pelvic Floor Physical Therapy Compliance?

brief_summary.textblock: The investigators intend to measure compliance with attending pelvic floor physical therapy (PFPT) in a Urogynecology population by randomizing patients to either viewing a four minute educational video or reading a handout explaining the therapy.

detailed_description.textblock:
Patients who have been interviewed, examined, and a plan has been made by the treating physicians in the Female Pelvic Medicine & Reconstructive Surgery practice will be invited to participate at the end of the visit if the patient and physician mutually agree that PFPT is the treatment modality to pursue.
If she agrees to participate, she will be consented and randomized. If she is randomized to standard counseling, she will be given the standard handout to read. If she is randomized to the intervention, she will receive the standard handout and view the 4-minute educational video on an iPad.
At the conclusion of the counseling, patients will be asked if they have any additional questions, and these will be recorded and answered. The patient will also fill out a visual analog scale about how informed she feels regarding PFPT.

study_design_info.intervention_model_description: Participants are randomized to standard counseling for pelvic floor physical therapy (PFPT) or to an experimental counseling group that comprises both standard counseling and a 4-minute PFPT educational video using a 1:1 allocation
study_design_info.masking_description: No masking is used in this study

primary_outcome.measure: Number of Participants With Completed PT Visits
primary_outcome.description: The number of patients who completed at least half of their recommended PFPT visits is compared between those assigned to enhanced counseling versus standard counseling

secondary_outcome.description: The number of patients who initiated PFPT is compared between those assigned to enhanced counseling versus standard counseling
The number of patients who discharged from PFPT is compared between those assigned to enhanced counseling versus standard counseling
The number of days from referral to PFPT to the first PFPT visit is compared between those assigned to enhanced counseling versus standard counseling

secondary_outcome.measure: Change in Urogenital Distress From Baseline to 3 Months
secondary_outcome.description: Patients complete the Urinary Distress Inventory 6 (UDI-6) prior to beginning PFPT therapy and following PFPT therapy. The change in UDI-6 from baseline to 3 months following therapy is compared between those assigned to enhanced counseling versus standard counseling. The UDI-6 is an assessment of urogenital distress with a score range from 0 to 100, where higher scores indicate greater disability.

arm_group.description: Patients randomized to this arm receive experimental counseling on the importance of attending PFPT appointments. This includes the standard 2-page educational handout and a 4-minute educational video.
Patients randomized to this arm receive standard counseling on the importance of attending PFPT appointments. This includes the standard 2-page educational handout.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Patients who have prescribed PFPT by a treating physician in the Female Pelvic Medicine & Reconstructive Surgery practice
Exclusion Criteria:
- Patients â‰¤ 18 years old

Fitzgerald MP, Anderson RU, Potts J, Payne CK, Peters KM, Clemens JQ, Kotarinos R, Fraser L, Cosby A, Fortman C, Neville C, Badillo S, Odabachian L, Sanfield A, O'Dougherty B, Halle-Podell R, Cen L, Chuai S, Landis JR, Mickelberg K, Barrell T, Kusek JW, Nyberg LM; Urological Pelvic Pain Collaborative Research Network. Randomized multicenter feasibility trial of myofascial physical therapy for the treatment of urological chronic pelvic pain syndromes. Tibaek S, Dehlendorff C. Do women with pelvic floor dysfunction referred by gynaecologists and urologists at hospitals complete a pelvic floor muscle training programme? A retrospective study, 1992-2008. Int Urogynecol J. 2013 Aug;24(8):1361-9. doi: 10.1007/s00192-012-2018-2. Epub 2013 Jan 5.

patient_data.ipd_description: There is no plan to share individual participant data with other researchers

provided_document.document_type: Study Protocol and Statistical Analysis Plan

participant_flow.recruitment_details: Patients were recruited from August 2016 through March 2017 (7 months) from a tertiary care female pelvic medicine and reconstructive surgery practice.

group.title: Experimental Counseling
group.description: Patients randomized to this arm receive experimental counseling on the importance of attending pelvic floor physical therapy (PFPT) appointments. This includes the standard 2-page educational handout and a 4-minute educational video.

group.description: Patients randomized to this arm receive standard counseling on the importance of attending PFPT appointments. This includes the standard 2-page educational handout.

outcome.title: Number of Participants With Completed PT Visits
outcome.description: The number of patients who completed at least half of their recommended PFPT visits is compared between those assigned to enhanced counseling versus standard counseling
outcome.population: This analysis comprises only the participants who were randomized and had follow-up PFPT completion information available

group.description: Patients randomized to this arm receive experimental counseling on the importance of attending PFPT appointments. This includes the standard 2-page educational handout and a 4-minute educational video.

measure.title: Number of Participants With Completed PT Visits
measure.description: The number of patients who completed at least half of their recommended PFPT visits is compared between those assigned to enhanced counseling versus standard counseling
measure.population: This analysis comprises only the participants who were randomized and had follow-up PFPT completion information available

category.title: Completed half of the recommended visits
Did not complete half of the recommended visits

analysis.groups_desc: The null hypothesis is that there is no difference in the odds of completing half of the recommended PFPT visits between those assigned to standard versus experimental counseling

outcome.title: Initiation of PFPT
outcome.description: The number of patients who initiated PFPT is compared between those assigned to enhanced counseling versus standard counseling
outcome.population: This analysis comprises all participants who were randomized

measure.title: Initiation of PFPT
measure.description: The number of patients who initiated PFPT is compared between those assigned to enhanced counseling versus standard counseling
measure.population: This analysis comprises all participants who were randomized

analysis.groups_desc: The null hypothesis is that there is no difference in the odds of initiating PFPT between those assigned to standard versus experimental counseling

outcome.description: The number of patients who discharged from PFPT is compared between those assigned to enhanced counseling versus standard counseling

group.description: Patients randomized to this arm receive experimental counseling on the importance of attending PFPT appointments. This includes the standard 2-page educational handout and a 4-minute educational video.

group.title: Standard Counseling

measure.title: PFPT Discharge
measure.description: The number of patients who discharged from PFPT is compared between those assigned to enhanced counseling versus standard counseling
measure.population: This analysis comprises only the participants who were randomized and had follow-up PFPT completion information available

analysis.groups_desc: The null hypothesis is that there is no difference in the odds of discharge from PFPT between those assigned to standard versus experimental counseling
analysis.method_desc: The statistical test of the hypothesis excludes the three individuals with unknown PFPT discharge status

outcome.title: Days to Initiation of PFPT
outcome.description: The number of days from referral to PFPT to the first PFPT visit is compared between those assigned to enhanced counseling versus standard counseling
outcome.population: This analysis comprises only the participants who were randomized and initiated PFPT

group.title: Experimental Counseling
group.description: Patients randomized to this arm receive experimental counseling on the importance of attending PFPT appointments. This includes the standard 2-page educational handout and a 4-minute educational video.

group.title: Standard Counseling
group.description: Patients randomized to this arm receive standard counseling on the importance of attending PFPT appointments. This includes the standard 2-page educational handout.

measure.title: Days to Initiation of PFPT
measure.description: The number of days from referral to PFPT to the first PFPT visit is compared between those assigned to enhanced counseling versus standard counseling
measure.population: This analysis comprises only the participants who were randomized and initiated PFPT

analysis.groups_desc: Among those who initiated PFPT therapy, the null hypothesis is that there is no difference in the number of days to initiating PFPT therapy between those assigned to standard versus experimental counseling

outcome.title: Change in Urogenital Distress From Baseline to 3 Months
outcome.description: Patients complete the Urinary Distress Inventory 6 (UDI-6) prior to beginning PFPT therapy and following PFPT therapy. The change in UDI-6 from baseline to 3 months following therapy is compared between those assigned to enhanced counseling versus standard counseling. The UDI-6 is an assessment of urogenital distress with a score range from 0 to 100, where higher scores indicate greater disability.
outcome.population: This analysis comprises only the participants who were randomized and had pre-PFPT and post-PFPT UDI-6 scores available

group.title: Experimental Counseling
group.description: Patients randomized to this arm receive experimental counseling on the importance of attending PFPT appointments. This includes the standard 2-page educational handout and a 4-minute educational video.

group.title: Standard Counseling
group.description: Patients randomized to this arm receive standard counseling on the importance of attending PFPT appointments. This includes the standard 2-page educational handout.

measure.title: Change in Urogenital Distress From Baseline to 3 Months
measure.description: Patients complete the Urinary Distress Inventory 6 (UDI-6) prior to beginning PFPT therapy and following PFPT therapy. The change in UDI-6 from baseline to 3 months following therapy is compared between those assigned to enhanced counseling versus standard counseling. The UDI-6 is an assessment of urogenital distress with a score range from 0 to 100, where higher scores indicate greater disability.
measure.population: This analysis comprises only the participants who were randomized and had pre-PFPT and post-PFPT UDI-6 scores available

analysis.groups_desc: The null hypothesis is that there is no difference in the change from pre-PFPT to post-PFPT UDI-6 scores between those assigned to standard versus experimental counseling

reported_events.time_frame: Adverse event data were collected for 11 months

certain_agreements.pi_employee: All Principal Investigators ARE employed by the organization sponsoring the study.
certain_agreements.restrictive_agreement: There is NOT an agreement between Principal Investigators and the Sponsor (or its agents) that restricts the PI's rights to discuss or publish trial results after the trial is completed.

clinical_results.limitations_and_caveats: There are no limitations or caveats to report
